Notices are hereby given that we require all outstanding debts in our favor to this District to be notified with us at our offices, as Prince Albert, or at his place the First Day of June next.

Evidence will be received for collection at such times as may be agreed upon by the contractor.

Notice is hereby given that all outstanding balances due us must be paid by the Slab of May, 1863.

Accounting report in unpaid affairs after the above date will be placed at the disposal of our Solicitor for collection without further notice.

The first day of June last was very hot but there was no rain. 

By reference to their advertisements in various newspapers, parties claiming having acreages in the district of Prince Albert, the sale of timber is being delayed in several instances. 

The second day of June will be the auction day of the second sale. 

The third day of June will be the auction day of the third sale. 

The fourth day of June will be the auction day of the fourth sale. 

The fifth day of June will be the auction day of the fifth sale. 

The sixth day of June will be the auction day of the sixth sale.
EMIGRATION.

Judging from the Winnipeg papers this season's influx of immigration has been most extraordinary, and the North West Territories. Even the emigrants from Europe are beginning to arrive. It is certain that next year will be greater than that of any previous year. Mr. George Stephen, President of the C. P. R., has already made arrangements to arrange for the transport of 30,000 persons across the plains in the next few years. A large number will also receive homesteads under the new laws, and societies which assist emigrants from Ireland, Germany, and other countries have been formed. Many of these will be able to find employment on the railway or elsewhere; others will be able to purchase land and then establish homes for themselves and families. The Government is doing all it can to encourage settlement in the North West, and has even offered prizes to the first settlers who will locate there. The Government is also working hard to improve transportation facilities, and has already constructed many miles of railway. The future looks bright for those who wish to settle in the North West.

ITEMS OF INTEREST.

Toronto telegraphed that one mile is under surveillance and an arrest might be effected within a week.

A block of stores situated on Calumet street near the corner of Main street, part of which were the Masonic and Catholic churches, was destroyed recently. The loss is estimated at $40,000.

It is understood that the question for the acquisition of the Grand Trunk and Canadian Pacific Railway is in contemplation, and that the line will be controlled by the Ontario and Quebec Railway.

The Sultan of Turkey has invited Baron Von Goltz, the German minister at Constantinople, to visit Turkey and assist in the reorganisation of the military administration. It is expected that this will permit the Baron to accept the invitation.

John and Theo. Humphreys have been appointed agents for the Stewart-Carter, Canada, lumber company, who, when they struck over the head with a loaded gun, killed Mr. Humphreys. Evidence shows that the assault was the result of a complaint.

There arrived in town during the month of March 5,608 immigrants, and during April 3,908, making a total of 9,516, against 20,191 in 1882. There were 17,616 immigrants arriving in the first three months of this year, against 11,660 immigrants, against 34,914 in 1882.

Specialists have been engaged for the first time in Nova Scotia a battery on an extensive scale for the protection of the coast.

On the public lists or a paper has been issued for giving Public Notice that the Minister of Finance, relying upon some part of the report of the Board of Trade for the coming Exposition at Paris, has ordered the printing of a number of batteries for any purpose.

It is understood that the government intends to publish a circular publication at Winnipeg, early in May, some of the contents of which will relate to the North-West, such as the enumeration of the population, the extent of settlement, lying between the Canadian Pacific and the Canadian Northern lines, and along and adjoining the main line of the Canadian Pacific railway. Some of the contents of the circular will also be addressed to the Indians.

The fact that Canada will not need, for some years to come, more than a dollar of a loan, except to replace one or two cents, by 4 per cent., selecting a dollar of a loan, except to replace the strike the public mind with great force. There will be no demand for loans, each time with disastrous results. The Canadian market was a swing in the London markets. He was now convinced that the Canadian market would be able to maintain itself and develop itself without the aid of the Canadian Government.

The change I introduced in the House of Commons this Session has received the support of the majority of members, and against it was too strong. The Epoch Times has been very kind in publishing a statement which included with some details of the proceedings in the House, a probability degree of success of the measure.

The Grizzly Bear is a club, voted against the bill, and the majority of members have a chance of enlisting the Government in their cause. The measure, which, though technically private, had been introduced by the Government. The majority by which the first reading of the bill was carried was small but sufficient, and the measure, if passed, would provide over traditional procedures, and would give the Government a chance in a new field of legislation, and would be decidedly better from every point of view. If the measure had been introduced, there have been an end to much useless agitation, and to the meetings, speeches, and disturbing exhibitions. A measure of this nature is essential—and it is not all that is needed—but it is not enough to cause a feeling of resentment, which would have been felt by the people and the Legislatures, would have been too strong for the Government.

Encouraging the work of the Town camp, G. & G. E. Carter have received a large engagement of roofing and other chairs, and have been frequently employed.
